markdownRemark.html:
1. Default Parameters

ES5:

    function(firstname, lastname, nationality) {
        this.firstName = firstName;
        this.lastName = lastName;
        this.nationality = nationality === undefined ? "Indian" : nationality
    }

ES6: we can put the default values right in the signature of the functions:

    function(firstname, lastname, nationality="Indian") {
        this.firstName = firstName;
        this.lastName = lastName;
        this.nationality = nationality;
    }
  1. Template Literals
    let firstName = 'Peter';
    const yearOfBirth = 1980;
    
    function calcAge(year) {
        return 2018 - year;
    }

ES5: We had to break the string like below

    console.log('This is ' + firstName + '. He was born in ' + yearOfBirth + '. Today, he is ' + calcAge(yearOfBirth) + ' years old.');

ES6: In ES6 we can use a new syntax ${firstName} inside of the back-ticked string

    console.log(`This is ${firstName} . He was born in ${yearOfBirth}. Today, he is ${calcAge(yearOfBirth)} years old.`);
  1. Multi-line Strings

ES5: In ES5, we had to use like below 

    var strData = 'Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry,\n\t'
    + 'Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s\n\t'
    + 'when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book,\n\t'

ES6: ES6, simply use the backticks:

    var roadPoem = `Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry,
    Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s,
    when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book`
  1. Destructuring Assignment

ES5: In ES5, we had to use like below 

    var employee = ['Peter', 28];
    var name = employee[0];
    var age = employee[1];

ES6: In ES6, we can replace the ES5 code above with below code:

    
    let employee = ['Peter', 28];
    let { name, age } = employee;
  1. Arrow Functions

I love this feature. The flat arrows are amazing ..

ES5: In ES5, we had to use like below 

    const years = [1980, 1985, 1982, 1987];
    var ages = years.map(function(el) {
        return 2018 - el;
    });
    console.log(ages);

ES6: In ES6, we can replace the ES5 code with arrow functions:

    
    const years = [1980, 1985, 1982, 1987];
    let ages = years.map(el => 2016 - el);
    console.log(ages);
